comments.commentBody: Speaking of OPTICAL ILLUSIONs...  after filling out TRace and aTRa I could only see "TR" in the SW corner and so although I had correctly filled PART ON_ for "Succession Starter" I kept reading PATRON_   I decided it had to mean serving a customer, starting with PATRON I  and the alternative to Jumper would be a SIT SHOT...  anybody ever seen a shot taken from a sitting position??

OK. This is a kick. Not the asymmetry, which is just one more neat trick from my favorite constructor. (Enjoyed his commentary.) But the fact that it took me exactly 44 minutes to do this. (See #1 above). At least the number is symmetrical!

A bit of awkwardness in the northeast, but otherwise a great puzzle. I'd say a Study in Black and White but that would be too corny.

Lucretia Mott is worth googling for those not familiar with her. A true pioneer in both women's suffrage and abolitionist movements, co-founder of Swarthmore, etc. We need more like her today.

Oregonians join you in prayer this evening.

We also caution a rush to judgement of those who are trying to close the well. We don't have all the facts at this time and this is not the time to scapegoat anyone. Too many are suffering as it is now.

There will be time enough after this nightmare is history to correct errors and prevent this from happening again.

I'm a little tired of reading comments that say things like "yes, it's all well and good to gripe about oil, but we all need it all the time, so get over it." While I agree that we are not going to be oil-free anytime soon, it is possible to drive your car LESS, to have a car that uses LESS gas per mile, to use LESS plastics, to support agriculture that uses LESS giant gas-guzzling machinery, to make your home more efficient so you use LESS gas to heat it, or simply to use LESS heat.

For so much talk about personal responsibility in the financial sense, why is there so little in the environmental sense? Yes, you will still drive your car, heat your home, and use plastics. But you can do all of them less, and if everyone did them less, we would need less, much much less, gas/oil. Remember how much people scoffed at Obama's now long-ago suggestion that everyone do simple things like keep the pressure in your tires at the correct level, so that your car gets better mileage?

Every person does make a difference, especially if there are millions of people making a difference.

Reminds me of an Onion article: 'How Bad For The Environment Can Throwing Away One Plastic Bottle Be?' 30 Million People Wonder

http://www.theonion.com...
Fine them per day they don't stop the leak... $10 million a day.  Nothing like a market-based incentive to get a company to do something...

Actually the U.S. is a pretty safe place to drive compared to Russia,, Greece, Brazil, Pakistan, India, Mexico and the entire continent of Africa. We need to stop this scaremongering and put our traffic fatalities in proper context.

http://en.wikipedia.org...

This problem can be solved in three stages:

1.) Vastly improve the standards and benchmarks for qualifiying for a driver's license. Quit gearing the test for lowest common denominator (out of a box of cracker jacks).

2.) Improve the quality and durability of the roads and signage and road markings.

3.) Over-engineer cars and trucks, safer, more fuel-efficient, and make sure they have annual inspections, that cars have brakes, seatbelts, airbags, no exhaust pipe hanging off them, bumpers, working turn signals, brake lights etc.

4.) Enforcement, no hands on cell phones, no texting, no makeup, shaving, feeding yourself or children.

5.) Faster speed limits, why? Because at faster speeds you have to be more focused, you cannot afford distraction.

I think Kitman has it right. Alcohol and cell phones are a huge preventable cause of accidents and traffic deaths. Enforce the laws, and tax vehicles based on weight -- that would eliminate SUVs. I suspect people would drive more defensively in smaller cars.

If auto companies don't understand how to create a cell phone dead spot in a specific area, they should simply ask AT&T Wireless.

Comment 1 by John of Portland provides focus on the differences in fatal accident demographics. Beyond these intractable correlations, how about we reestablish a rational baseline with a return of Driver Education to high schools.

The value of a quality Driver Ed program outstrips the value of paying for varsity sports or foreign languages. I would gladly pay higher property taxes than dodge teenagers in SUV's at 3:00 P.M. Better yet, have students ride the city bus. Sorry I forgot; all the schools are built in suburban nowhere!

The solution here is simple but costly: increase the quality and reach of public transportation. The more people we can get out of cars and into buses, trains, boats, vans or other forms of public transportation, the more lives we can save and the more injuries we can prevent. This is not, to put it mildly, a popular point of view in this country. Even less popular is the idea of walking to work or riding a bike to the store instead of driving a car. Yet these are real solutions to a terrible problem. When America sets its mind to fixing a problem, it gets remarkable results. Technology can help us solve some traffic and accident related problems on our highways, but combining technology with public transportation is probably the quickest and best way to save lives, regain lost time, and prevent injuries.

Poor handling over weight cars cause a lot of death,don't stop well.People follow way to close,don't look to prevent accidents and don't even know whare the brake peddle is anymore. I ride a motorcycle so i know how to drive and ride better than most people and have gone though extra driving training that helps me-speed is not the biggest problem at all-its poor drivers

Nice pairing of FEY and LEMON.

I remember when Natalie left and they were reduced to 9,999 Maniacs.

I wanted "emoticon" for symbol of electromotive force.

There's no "I" in TEMA!

Oh, and the grid does have symmetry, it's just "var.".

The bottom line, it seems to me, is that nobody has a clue how to stop this thing which will turn out to be the biggest oil spill not just in US history, but in world history. And if this gunk somehow manages to get into the gulf stream, we could have oil washing up on the beaches of Europe and thousands of species of marine life killed worldwide.
This could literally be Apocalypse.

And while we are casting blame around,I hope that all of you SUV owners are proud of yourselves. You contributed to this castastrophe as much as anybody.

BP will continue to report that their efforts seem to be working until it becomes very evident that it isn't.  They've underestimated (or admitted) that the flow is 5-10 LESS than what it is.  They have multiple breaks in the line, not just one.  They've been lying since the get go.  And the government claims to be in complete control of a situation that is out of control.  Doesn't restore MY faith!

It is very difficult to rectify the fact that, no less than two weeks prior to this quite preventable environmental tragedy, President Obama had the gall stand up on the podium at Andrews Air Force Base and give pretty much carte blanche approval for more future deep water oil exploration, thus folding to the R-crowd, without the benefit of having asked for, or performed one ounce of due diligence, on behalf of MMS Office corruption, in fact long known about, in government political circles, since at least October '08. He assumed. A grave grave error on his part. I think it is fair to say, we expected much better.

I've given up on him. He's a lawyer, and a politician. The survival of Porpoises, Sea Turtles, Brown Pelicans, fragile ecosystem don't enter into his world, and what little they do, they are apparently, just the cost, of doing business.

Such a shame.
We are "The United States of America" and we repond where help is needed. The Gulf tates are not standing alone. Watch it happen as soon as we get the word.

It seems that every single thing BP says is a lie. The govt buys every single word of it. This am the world was convinced that the "top kill" worked. BP stock rallied 7%. The gushing crud wasn't oil anymore; it was "mud". Now we find that they weren't even pumping "mud" when they made that claim. Don't you feel insulted by that BS.

IF the leaking riser is 21" diameter and if you believe the velocity of the spewing plume is 20 mph out of the pipe, the volume would be >200,000 barrels per day.

Just another sad, ugly and depressing reminder of our ubiquitous addiction to oil. Horrifying to think this undersea pipe is still gushing tonnes of toxic crude into the Caribbean even as I write this!
What is clear from this disaster is that deepwater drilling (~5000 ft) and the logistics involved are extremely risky. Suspending leases on drilling in Alaska in 150 ft of water doesn't follow.
Anyone else see a striking parallel between the... let's say weathered... industries of coal and oil where regulations have been overlooked and the repercussions of these oversights are mind-numbing?

Regulations can help. But they are also a remedial step to a dysfunctional system. To change corporate behavior you have to change the incentives of employees, who are mostly judged by their contribution to profitability and how happy they make their bosses. Let's take a brief look at the incentives of this disaster's actors: The rig's owners are incented to maximize charges to BP for using the rig, even when no oil is ready to be pumped. They benefit by not cutting corners. BP is incented to stop losing money on wells that are not producing revenue yet. They are incented to cut corners. Politicians are incented to please everyone, especially the people screaming the loudest or have the most power. They are incented to be ineffective. And government employees work to make sense of and enforce policies that they stopped trying to rationalize long ago. They are incented to enforce rules that are ineffective and keeping their heads down to not get shot in the cross-fire. When everyone working together have totally different agendas and opposing incentives, something is eventually going to go wrong and finger-pointing will be all the rage. I don't see these incentives changing in my lifetime. It seems that bands-aids are the best we can hope for.
I hope that they are able to fix the problem soon. The sad thing is that people and communities are being affected by the spill.

Consumer Energy Taxes. The only proven method to reduce energy consumption.

Federal Excise Tax on Road Fuels need to increase -- Now.

This is something which could be done expediously and cheaply. There is already an excise tax on gasoline, which could be increased very quickly.

At least one thing is way ahead of schedule.  Original forecast was that BP’s Deepwater Horizon Gulf of Mexico oil spill would surpass that of Exxon’s Valdez oil spill in Prince William Sound of 250,000 barrels of crude oil by Father’s Day, 14 June 2010.  BP/Transocean/Halliburton and M.M.S. must be proud that they are now responsible for the most devastating human-caused environmental disasters ever to occur in history.

It is long past time we repealed this unfortunate legacy of the Clinton era. So ironic that opponents of the measure claim it's an attempt to push a liberal social agenda! although I suppose equal rights might be considered thus. I'm pretty sure those who've volunteered for the armed forces will be able to deal with the fact that their country stands for such equality.
